text.p: These are the leading stories in the Turkish press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Reports that military leaders' phones were tapped are followed by allegations that many politicians, including new Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz, have had their phones tapped.
- A briefing to new Finance Minister Zekeriya Temizel shows the budget deficit in the first five months of the year amounted to 530 trillion lira ($3.5 billion).
- A series of explosions at a munitions factory in the central Anatolian town of Kirikkale injures many and sends locals fleeing from the area.
- A business group's report says Turkey imported $7 billion of weapons between 1989-1994.
- Police have begun an investigation into the possibility that sabotage was the cause of the munitions factory explosions.
- A parliamentary commission is to look into allegations of corruption in privatisations while Tansu Ciller was in power.
- A top police official accused of tapping the phones of military leaders says he will return to Turkey from the United States and explain his activities.
- The new government is to enter dialogue with the International Monetary Fund as part of an initiative to seek foreign borrowing.
- A council being set up to investigate financial crimes is preparing a document that will set out ways of monitoring money laundering.
- The new government is planning to give civil servants a wage rise for the next six months which will not exceed 25 percent.
- The populists policies of the former Islamist-led government will lead to a rise in inflation to 90 percent.
